subject: Re: [junit] Bumblebee 0.2, feedback requested
msgSnippet: Hi David, I hope you ll enjoy it. Drop me a line if you need any help. I d also like to know what disturbs and what you miss. If you would have some feedback
messageBody:
Hi David,

I hope you'll enjoy it. Drop me a line if you need any help. I'd also
like to know what disturbs and what you miss.

If you would have some feedback on the JUnit integration in the
implementation that would be great, too. :-)

Cheers
Daniel

On Nov 19, 2007 8:03 PM, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>

> giving it a spin--I had a similar thought a month or two ago, and I'm
> glad to see you already did the hard work!
>
> David

> On Nov 13, 2007 2:45 AM, Daniel Brolund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
> > Hi Nat,
> > I see that my approach is very similar to yours, and the limited
> > response I've gotten so far is pretty much the same: you better see
> > how well the tests describe the code!
> >
> > One other interesting effect is that after a while I start to get
> > documentation-driven tests, meaning that I put myself in the end users
> > position, write the documentation for the feature I'm about to
> > implement (as a good method name and a comment in the test method),
> > write the test and asserts for it, and then implement the feature.
> > After having run the tests the documentation is ready to be reviewed,
> > it takes about 3 secs on my computer (and approx 1 sec is starting up
> > JRuby).
> >
> > Right now it is a bit awkward since I write tests for the
> > documentation features which are mainly comments. I am, however, using
> > documentation asserts (in the comments) that actually shows up in the
> > JUnit report in Eclipse, so I get pretty good feedback. One way of
> > putting it is that I'm test-driving the documentation while I'm
> > documentation-driving the tests... :-)
> >
> > I'm still not sure exactly the best place to use Bumblebee (or
> > Protest), but I know that for API-documentation it will definitely be
> > a good thing.
> > With TDDoc I experimented with Abbot tests ("GUI-clicking") where I
> > complemented the comments with images by pulling bitmaps from the
> > Swing frames, and then generating JavaHelp files (using docbook), and
> > it actually worked (with a few minor flaws). It should be possible to
> > do the same thing with Bumblebee. I don't want to start a new thread
> > on whether GUI-clicking is a good way to test your application (I
> > generally think it is not), but with automatically generated JavaHelp
> > in the equation the balance might change a bit for some people.
> >
> > Cheers
> > Daniel, still wanting more feedback
> >
> >
> >

> > > test code. I wrote a tool & test framework with similar goals for

> > >
> > > One interesting effect I found when using Protest is that the generated

> > > On 11/11/2007, Daniel Brolund <daniel.brolund@...> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Hi all,
> > > > I would really appreciate some feedback on a small framework I'm
> > > > writing for JUnit 4.4.
> > > >
> > > > I call it Bumblebee, and the purpose of it is to use comments and the
> > > > structures in the test-suites/cases/methods to create
> "human-readable"
> > > > documentation. It is especially well suited for writing snippet-heavy
> > > > documentation.
> > > >
> > > > In short, Bumblebee gets events from the execution of the tests
> > > > (suites/classes/methods) and then parses the classes and methods for
> > > > specific comments to include.
> > > >
> > > > By default it adds the de-camelcased names of the
> suites/cases/methods
> > > > as headings (a la agile dox), and the contained comments becomes the
> > > > paragraphs.
> > > >
> > > > The comments are actually handled as Ruby-strings that get executed
> in
> > > > a Bumblebee execution context before being added to the output. The
> > > > execution context is
> > > > a kind of DSL for including code-snippets and other things needed,
> and
> > > > one of the core ideas of Bumblebee is that you should be able to
> > > > extend that functionality easily.
> > > >
> > > > More detailed information about Bumblebee can be found at:
> > > >
> > > > http://www.agical.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html
> > > >
> > > > which is of course generated with Bumblebee. :-)
> > > >
> > > > The concept of Bumblebee is the same as for TDDoc, which me and
> Joakim
> > > > Ohlrogge wrote some time ago as an add-on for RMock. Unfortunately,
> > > > TDDoc became a bit of a dead-end technically, and Joakim and I
> thought
> > > > it would be a good idea to start fresh. I happened to have the time
> at
> > > > the time and I started it up. So, if you like Bumblebee, give half of
> > > > your credits to Joakim!
> > > >
> > > > This is an early release, and I will be very happy for any feedback I
> > > > can get to improve it.
> > > >
> > > > Cheers
> > > > Daniel Brolund
